header.title: The Onyx Tablet of Set
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Left-Hand Path, Setianism, Magical Philosophy, Organizational Documents

central_thesis: The Onyx Tablet of Set serves as the authoritative handbook and policy guide for the Priesthood (III° and higher Initiates) of the Temple of Set. It delineates the unique nature, profound responsibilities, ethical guidelines, and operational protocols of the Priesthood, emphasizing the continuous process of individual Xeper (Self-Creation) and its collective manifestation to fulfill the Temple's mission as a vehicle for Set's influence in the world. It aims to clarify philosophical underpinnings and practical mechanics for maintaining the integrity and effective functioning of the Temple's highest echelons.

structure_content.summary: Outlines the Temple of Set's origin from the Church of Satan, its twofold purpose (haven for Initiates, preserving experience for humanity), and the Priesthood's unique role as a manifestation of Set's consciousness. Describes the Onyx Tablet as a restricted handbook for the Priesthood within the 'Jeweled Tablets of Set' series.

Legal document establishing the Temple of Set as a non-profit religious corporation in California, detailing its religious purpose, general powers, and limitations (e.g., no lobbying). Lists initial directors and provisions for asset distribution upon dissolution.

structure_content.chapter_title: By-Laws of the Temple of Set
structure_content.summary: Defines the six degrees of Temple membership, their recognition and expulsion processes, and the roles of the Council of Nine, High Priest, Executive Director, and Treasurer. Establishes guidelines for Orders, Pylons, amendments, and interpretation, forming the core administrative structure.

structure_content.chapter_title: U.S. Internal Revenue Service Federal Tax Exemption
structure_content.summary: Official IRS letter confirming the Temple of Set's 501(c)(3) tax-exempt status as a public charity, allowing tax-deductible contributions and outlining reporting requirements.

structure_content.chapter_title: California State Franchise Tax Board Exemption
structure_content.summary: Official California state letter confirming the Temple of Set's exemption from state franchise or income tax under Section 23701d as a religious corporation, with reporting requirements for changes.

structure_content.chapter_title: High Priest of Set: Policy Statements
structure_content.summary: Sets forth High Priest policies regarding the supervision of Orders and Pylons, financial protocols, and the structure and access restrictions of the various 'Jeweled Tablets of Set' volumes (Crystal, Ruby, Onyx, Sapphire, Amethyst, Topaz).

Provides comprehensive guidelines for behavior, communication, and formal grievance resolution within the Temple, particularly for Priests. Emphasizes courtesy, respect, confidentiality, and a structured approach to conflict to prevent escalation to higher authorities.
Details the purpose, protocol, and technical aspects of the '3admin-l' email list for administrative discussions among the Priesthood, stressing message confidentiality and proper conduct.

Describes the '3forum-l' email list for philosophical, religious, and initiatory discussions within the Priesthood, emphasizing its role as a platform for teaching techniques and new projects, with a focus on principle over personal attacks.

structure_content.chapter_title: Getting the Dung Ball Rolling: a note to the Priesthood Forum
structure_content.summary: Poses key questions to stimulate discussion among Priests on practical III° activities outside the Temple, maintaining Priesthood status, the real-world impact of initiatory experience, Black Magical development, and interaction with mundane society.

structure_content.chapter_title: Cerberus at the Gate: Some Guidelines For Meeting New Candidates
structure_content.summary: Provides guidance for Priests interviewing prospective members, focusing on assessing ambition, original thought, antinomianism, humor, and avoiding religiosity. Stresses security, meeting in public, and the importance of accurate representation of the Temple.

Discusses evolving criteria for II° Recognition, emphasizing understanding Setian philosophy, demonstrable magical ability, loyalty to the Temple, and viewing initiation as a lifelong process. Suggests a year-long tryout and follow-up for new Adepts.

Further elaborates on the II° Recognition process, providing specific questions for candidates to evaluate their comprehension of Setian principles, their current initiatory state, the function of an Adept, and personal transformations since joining the Temple.

Offers ten suggestions for Priests to enhance their interaction with Set, including broadening personal initiation, community research, discovering magical history, fostering tolerance, explaining Xeper, Setian gatherings, finding a confidante, and self-affirmation.

Addresses the 'awakening' of the Priesthood as a period of intense dialogue. Outlines five disciplines for discourse: dedication to principle, civility, Temple spirit, increasing initiatory activities, and expanding Priesthood awakening. Proposes specialized administrative and initiatory mailing lists.

Offers guidance for new Priests on applying their elevated state, focusing on the 'Need for Work' (doing the Priestly job even when difficult), the 'Need to See Xeper' (being inspired by others' Xeper), the 'Need to see Struggles as Training', and the 'Need for a Personal Connection with Set'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Church of Satan Letter of III° Nomination
structure_content.summary: A historical document from 1974 outlining the rigorous criteria and year-long evaluation process for ordination to the Priesthood of Mendes within the Church of Satan, emphasizing ability, social effectiveness, and application of Satanic principles, distinct from lay membership.

Discusses the principles guiding Priesthood Recognitions, asserting that a Master's 'magical noesis' (personal judgment) is paramount over rigid criteria. Advocates for dialogue among Masters, a 'green light' approach, and avoiding undue delays, while acknowledging that Priesthood is an 'inherently unnatural event'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Reply to Neilly on III° Recognitions
structure_content.summary: A response affirming the importance of individual Master judgment in III° Recognitions, supporting dialogue, and emphasizing a 'green light' policy unless strong reasons exist otherwise. Reinforces that Priesthood is an 'inherently unnatural event' requiring conscious striving, and that disagreements should not impede the process.

Explains the historical context of expulsion authority within the Temple, inherited from the Church of Satan, and how III°+ members are trusted with the discretion to expel I°/II° members. Outlines the procedural steps and appeal process for such decisions.

An agenda for a workshop designed for Adepts nearing Priesthood, covering individual expectations, administrative responsibilities ('Outer Temple'), protocol, ethics, leadership, the Priesthood's societal role, II° recognition, current issues, and the 'Inner Temple' (Intellect and the Heart).

structure_content.chapter_title: The Nine Steps for Setian Recovery
structure_content.summary: An adaptation of the Twelve Steps of Alcoholics Anonymous for Setians, focusing on addiction recovery through Setian principles. Emphasizes self-honesty, harnessing personal Will and magical tools, making amends, and continuous self-inventory as a path to Xeper.

Discusses the principles of judgment and discernment for expelling members, distinguishing clear-cut cases from complex ones. Provides guidance on when to counsel members considering leaving, emphasizing self-reflection for those who choose to depart from the Temple.

Addresses misconceptions about the II° (Adept) degree, defining Recognition as a 'boost' for self-direction and a magical link. Outlines essential qualities for Adeptship: understanding Setian philosophy, magical ability, Temple loyalty, and virtues like discernment, curiosity, humor, and cunning.

Presents a methodology for training Setians, addressing common weaknesses. It outlines four phases for initiators (Attraction, Polarization, Refinement, Articulation) to aid candidates in developing body, mind, emotions, and will, emphasizing hard work, self-transformation, and follow-through for new Adepts.

Explores the Temple of Set's role in human civilization as altering the matrix through individual development rather than direct control. Presents a seven-stage model of initiation (wandering, shock, daydreaming, second shock, the School, third shock, Work) and defines the characteristics of each stage.

Analyzes reasons for Priesthood resignations, including incorrect recognition, inability to sustain Xeper, strong disagreements with Temple direction, character failings, political machinations, life situations, and Xeper leading in divergent directions. Stresses understanding and support for departures based on healthy skepticism.

Discusses strategies for Priests to avoid burnout by segregating activities (family, career, Xeper, Priesthood, administration), employing time management, accepting undone tasks without 'fretting', and utilizing formal leaves of absence for personal initiation.

Explores the freedom and responsibility of the Priesthood in shaping the Temple's growth. Emphasizes demonstrating change through 'deeds of genius' rather than mere advocacy, suggesting Priests create five-year plans for Workings that positively impact the Temple.

Examines the historical and mythological context of the Priesthood of Set, drawing parallels with ancient Egyptian beliefs. Highlights Set's unique role as the 'god not of the gods', representing non-natural self-awareness, and the Temple's goal to restore this original apprehension, requiring contemplative study.

Contrasts the Priesthood of Set with conventional religions, defining it as consecrated to Set (a neter of non-nature), intensely personal, and for beings of high intelligence. Outlines three responsibilities (to Set, to self, to Temple) and discusses initiatory relationships, Orders, Pylons, and the Priesthood's role in Lesser and Greater Black Magic.

structure_content.chapter_title: Ceremony of Ordination to the Priesthood of Set
structure_content.summary: Provides the ritual text for Priesthood ordination, invoking the 'Great Flame of the Prince of Darkness'. It recounts Set's legacy and Xepera, symbolizing the initiate's embrace of eternal Priesthood and becoming a 'Self-Created One', a 'glory to your race and a brilliance before the Eye of Set'.

structure_content.chapter_title: On the Opening of the Mouth
structure_content.summary: Discusses the Priesthood's task of communicating personal initiation, linking it to the Egyptian 'Opening of the Mouth' rite. Explores the 'shock' and 'friction' experienced when a Priest feels compelled to speak, seeing it as part of the III° experience and an ongoing exploration of divinity.

structure_content.chapter_title: Notes on Forbidden Secrets, or Who Left the Voodoo Doll in the Rectory?
structure_content.summary: Explores 'The Awakening' as self-awareness, distinguishing between mundane and truly 'Elect' forms. Describes 'Xepera: The Cup of Knowledge' and 'Lucifer: Realization, Transmutation, Light' as processes of deep self-transformation and living one's magic.

Details the Setian path from human to Adept to Priest, emphasizing the crucial 'Focus' required at the III° level to integrate diverse experiences. Offers self-inquiry questions to help Priests find and maintain their unique focus, preventing disorientation and stagnation.

Explores the concept of Set's 'Love' as distinct from human emotion, primarily directed towards the 'Realization of his Gift' (Xeper) in individuals. It emphasizes that through diligent self-work to cultivate virtues like Courage and Determination, one facilitates opportunities for others to achieve Xeper.

Highlights the essential characteristics of the Priesthood: the unity in diversity of Xeper, serving as living examples of Setian philosophy, and facilitating self-realization in others. It underscores that the 'Gift of Set' is a prerequisite for achieving the 'Highest of Life' and self-consciousness.

Examines the question of Set's existence and nature within the Priesthood. It asserts that Set is defined by individual Priests through personal experience and contemplation, not blind faith. It discusses various interpretations of Set (entity, essence, self-created god, Platonic Form) and warns against dogmatism and limiting perceptions.

structure_content.chapter_title: When Set Recognized Devaset Akasha to His Priesthood
structure_content.summary: A personal account of an Initiate's journey to Priesthood, describing the subjective experience of 'created destiny' and self-definition. It illustrates the 'Recognition' of Set's presence and the Priest's role as an 'AEonic enhancer and supporter', distinct from personal gain, through developing 'perception' and 'understanding'.

Explores Set as the 'Form of isolate self-consciousness' and a force that initiates Xeper within humanity. It discusses transcending conventional myths and views Set's 'Gift' as a 'quickening' within the human organism, a multi-dimensional process of self-referral and continuous evolution.

key_concepts.definition: A religious organization dedicated to the Left-Hand Path, founded on the principle of Xeper, serving as a 'School' for initiatory development to foster self-creation and individual advancement. It aims to alter the matrix of human civilization through individual transformation.

The highest initiatory echelons of the Temple, responsible for leading, teaching, and serving as living exemplars of Setian philosophy and Xeper. Priests directly manifest Set's consciousness and are entrusted with safeguarding the Temple's integrity, operating with significant autonomy and responsibility.

The core principle of Setianism, meaning 'to Become' or 'Self-Creation.' It represents the ongoing, dynamic process of self-transformation, individuation, and the actualization of one's unique potential beyond natural and conventional limitations, driven by Will.

A philosophical and magical path emphasizing individual will, self-deification, and intentional transgression of conventional norms to achieve personal awakening and transcendence, in contrast to Right-Hand Path's submission to external deities or universal oneness.

Referred to as the 'Prince of Darkness' or the 'Form of isolate self-consciousness,' a neter (divine principle) of non-nature. Set's 'Gift' is the potential for Xeper within humans. His nature is subject to individual interpretation and experience within the Priesthood, ranging from an external entity to an indwelling essence or Platonic Form.

A lifelong, self-driven process of self-discovery, transformation, and awakening to one's true nature, progressing through six distinct degrees within the Temple (I° to VI°), each representing a deeper level of understanding and practical application of Setian principles.

An intuitive, direct knowing or insight, particularly crucial for Masters in discerning an Adept's readiness for Priesthood. It emphasizes personal, informed judgment over rigid, formalized criteria, reflecting the subjective yet verifiable nature of initiatory progress.

A multi-volume compendium of the Temple's official standing reference papers, policies, and philosophical/magical documents. Access is tiered by initiatory degree (Crystal, Ruby, Onyx, Sapphire, Amethyst, Topaz), ensuring information is presented appropriately for each level.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in the Onyx Tablet mandates that Priests actively embody Xeper through leadership, mentorship, and administrative engagement within the Temple’s structure. Priests serve as exemplars of Setian philosophy, guiding lower-degree initiates, contributing to Temple publications, and managing organizational elements like Pylons and Orders. This involves continuous self-reflection, the application of Black Magic (both Lesser for mundane influence and Greater for self-transformation), and real-world application of esoteric principles. The system emphasizes balancing individual initiatory growth with collective responsibility to strengthen Set's influence, requiring active participation in Temple administration, adherence to detailed protocols, and rigorous self-evaluation to maintain the Priesthood's integrity and effectiveness.
tools: Temple hierarchy (High Priest, Council of Nine, Executive Director, Orders, Pylons)
Jeweled Tablets of Set (as informational and doctrinal resources)
Dialogue and discussions (within Priesthood and with initiates)
rituals: Ceremony of Ordination to the Priesthood of Set
Ritual activities (general, for Pylon meetings, self-improvement)
Nine Steps for Setian Recovery (ritualized self-transformation)

relevant_quotes.text: The central, crucial characteristic of the Priesthood of Set is that, when an individual so consecrated expends the effort to do so, he or she may experience, represent, and manifest the consciousness of Set.
The Onyx Tablet of Set is to be safeguarded by each Initiate of the Priesthood in such a way that it cannot be accessed, taken, or copied by any non-Initiate of the Priesthood.

The responsibility and authority to determine all policies and programs of the Temple of Set, subject only to the provisions of these By-Laws, shall rest with the High Priest (or High Priestess) of Set.

The Temple of Set is an elitist organization. It does not try for neo-tribalism, it is not interested in retention of members. The Temple will retain members if and only if it is doing what it is designed to do. Returning the Temple to its Design with each conscious action is the Duty of the Priesthood.
Xeper is the actualization in the Objective Universe of Dynamism, a quality of the Core Self.

As Black Magic is merely a tool for use by magicians, so the Temple of Set as an institution is ultimately a vehicle for the identification and formalization of the Priesthood of Set, through whose soul flow the current of the Aeon of Set. Each Priest and Priestess of Set is a Temple of Set: a psyche so purified, educated, consecrated, and initiated that it has become a fit medium for the Prince of Darkness.
Set is whatever you define Set to be. We are not and should not be required to adopt one view over the other.

critical_analysis.relevance: The Onyx Tablet is an indispensable text for understanding the internal mechanics, philosophical underpinnings, and operational directives of the Temple of Set's Priesthood. It codifies the unique responsibilities, ethical framework, and initiatory expectations for its highest-degree members (III°+). By emphasizing Xeper as a continuous, individually driven process integrated with practical guidance for leadership, communication, and conflict resolution, it provides a vital blueprint for maintaining internal coherence and promoting the Temple's overarching goals. It navigates the tension between individual autonomy and collective organizational integrity, offering a practical model for a hierarchical esoteric body.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists exclusively of Initiates of the Priesthood (III° and higher) of the Temple of Set. It is explicitly restricted from lower degrees, non-Initiates, and the general public, as its content addresses sensitive policy, advanced initiatory concepts, and internal administrative procedures vital to the Priesthood's unique functions and the security of the organization.
